questions.question: Which of the following is the most common, preventable cause of mental retardation?

In a 4-month old, term infant with open posterior fontanelle and hypotonia, you suspectcongenital hypothyroidism and send thyroid studies. Which of the following is the mostcommon cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of permanent congenital hypothyroidism (80-85%of cases) > dyshormonogenesis (15%).Dysgenesis may involve ectopy, agenesis (absence) or hypoplasia (underdevelopment) of thethyroid gland. Dyshormonogenesis results from a defect in any of the steps in thyroid hormonebiosynthesis.*TSH - thyroid-stimulating hormone; TRH - thyroid-releasing hormoneAcquired hypothyroidism can be caused by iodine deficiency, thyroiditis, radiation, histiocytosis,and drugs. The most common cause of acquired hypothyroidism is autoimmune thyroiditis(Hashimoto's).Note: Mutation in PAX-8 gene is associated with congenital hypothyroidism and genitourinaryabnormalities such as renal agenesis.586Etiology of congenital hypothyroidism:Primary hypothyroidism:Thyroid dysgenesisThyroid dyshormonogenesisIodine deficiency (endemic goiter) Defect inthyroid hormone transport-Mutation inMCT8(monocarboxylatetransporter 8) geneMaternal antibodies- thyrotropin receptor-blocking antibody(TRBAb)Maternal medications- iodides, amiodarone, propylthiouracil, methimazole, radioiodineCentral (hypopituitary) hypothyroidism:TSH deficiency-mutation in TSH ẞ-subunit geneTRH deficiency- mutation in TRH geneTRH unresponsiveness-mutation in TRH receptor geneMultiple congenitalpituitary hormone deficiencieS

questions.question: You are called to see a 3-day-old, term neonate, who has not passed meconium yet. Onclinical examination, there is generalized hypotonia and the abdomen is slightly distendedwithout any evidence of ascites or hepatosplenomegaly. Incidentally, you also note a palpablegoitre in this baby. Laboratory investigations reveal low T4 and elevated TSH levels. Which ofthe following is the most likely cause for this child's condition?
questions.explanation: A history of decreased activity and late passage of meconium, associated with low T4 and highTSH is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism. In an infant with a palpable goitre, the likelydiagnosis is congenital hypothyroidism secondary to thyroid dyshormonogenesis.The most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism is thyroid dysgenesis but it is notassociated with goitre. Thyroid dyshormonogenesis results from the deficiency of one or moreenzymes involved in thyroid hormone synthesis/secretion.Congenital hypothyroidism can be:Goitrous (Palpable goitre)Thyroid dyshormonogenesisodine deficiencyPlacental passage of antithyroid drugsNon-goitrous (No palpable goitre)Thyroid dysgenesis Thyroid receptor blocking antibodiesCentral (hypopituitary) hypothyroidism

questions.question: 579At how many weeks of gestation does thyroxine secretion begin in a fetus?
questions.explanation: Thyroxine secretion begins in the fetus at 12 weeks of gestation.587The fetal thyroid arises from an outpouching of the foregut at the base of the tongue (foramencecum). It migrates to its normal location over the thyroid cartilage by 8-10 wk of gestation. Thebilobed shape of the thyroid is recognized by 7 weeks of gestation.

questions.question: An anxious mother has brought a 4-month-old baby with complaints that the baby is notfeeding well and is excessively sleepy all the time. Clinical examination reveals jaundice andhypotonia. His picture is provided below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The above picture shows a child with a protuberant abdomen, umbilical hernia, macroglossia, andedematous facies. Also, the infant is sluggish, has jaundice, feeding difficulties, and hypotonia, allof which suggests a diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism.Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism:• Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia- early sign (it is due to delayed maturation ofglucuronide conjugation)•Constipation- usually does not respond to treatment• Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures••Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentitionCardiovascular- slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edemaRespiratory- macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties• Haematological- macrocytic anaemia refractory to treatment with haematinics• Nervous system- hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness,and somnolence

questions.question: A newborn with abnormal neonatal screening tests was diagnosed with Pendred syndrome.Which of the following is not a feature of this syndrome?
questions.explanation: Sensorineural hearing loss is present in Pendred syndrome; not conductive hearing loss.Pendred syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder, caused by a mutation in the gene SLC26A4on chromosome 7, which codes for pendrin, a chloride-iodide transport protein common to thethyroid gland and the cochlea.Clinical features include sensorineural hearing loss and goitre with hypothyroidism. It is the mostcommon cause of syndromic deafness. The biochemical reason for hypothyroidism in patientswith Pendred syndrome is impaired iodide organification (resulting from a mutation in thePendrin gene).

questions.question: A 9-day-old infant has elevated TSH level and low T4 level on newborn screening. If thiscondition is left untreated, which of the following is most likely to be seen in this infant in thefirst few months of life?
questions.explanation: Elevated TSH levels and low T4 levels in a 9-day-old infant are suggestive of congenitalhypothyroidism. Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia is an early sign of congenitalhypothyroidism. It is due to delayed maturation of the hepatic glucuronide conjugation system.Hyperreflexia, hyperirritability and diarrhoea are seen in hyperthyroidism; not hypothyroidism.588Note:Kocher-Debré-Sémélaigne syndrome: The muscles are usually hypotonic in congenitalhypothyroidism. Rarely, hypothyroidism in infancy can be characterized by generalized muscularpseudohypertrophy, myxoedema, short stature and cretinism. Affected older children can have anathletic appearance. Boys are more prone to the development of the syndrome.

questions.question: During a rural health camp, a father brings a dull-looking baby with macroglossia and anumbilical hernia. On enquiry, you find out that the parents were told about a thyroid problemin the child at birth, for which they did not pursue any treatment. Which of the following isleast likely to be found in children with the given condition?
questions.explanation: A dull-looking face with macroglossia, and umbilical hernia in a child with a thyroid disorder areall indicative of congenital hypothyroidism. Craniosynostosis is not seen in neonatalhypothyroidism. It is seen in hyperthyroidism.Craniosynostosis refers to the premature fusion of sutures and closure of fontanelles and oftenresults in abnormal, triangular facies. In congenital hypothyroidism, there is delayed closure ofthe fontanelles. Palpable goitre, though not common, can be seen in cases of untreated thyroiddyshormonogenesis.

questions.question: As part of a quality improvement project undertaken by the maternal and child healthservices, you are evaluating the current practice of newborn screening and detection rates ofhypothyroidism in various community health centres. Which of the following statements isfalse?

options.A: Simultaneous measurement of T4 and TSH levels is the ideal method.
options.B: The sample is obtained by heel-prick between 1-5 days of life using dried blood spot.Newborn screening always detects the affected twin in same-sex twins.d) Primary TSH, with back up T4 is the most common strategy used.581Question 10:As an intern posted in paediatrics, you are asked to interpret the results of a heel prick testthat you performed on a newborn. Which of the following results is suggestive of primaryhypothyroidism?a) Low T4 level and low TSH levelb) Low T4 level and high TSH level
options.C: High T4 level and low TSH level
options.D: High T4 level and high TSH level

questions.explanation: Newborn screening can fail to detect the affected twin with hypothyroidism.Discordance for thyroid dysgenesis is the rule in monozygotic twins. The transfusion of euthyroidblood from the unaffected twin normalizes the serum levels of T4 and TSH in the affected twin,resulting in delayed or missed diagnoses. Therefore, a second sample for congenitalhypothyroidism screening at 14 days of age should be considered in monozygotic twins.Neonatal thyroid screening strategies:•Primarily TSH, backup T4; T4 is measured if TSH level is >20 mU/L•Primarily T4, backup TSH: TSH is measured only if T4 level is low•Concomitant T4 and TSH; it is the most sensitive methodNote: the sample is obtained after 24-48 hours, to minimize the false elevation of TSH values dueto normal post-delivery neonatal TSH surge.

questions.question: The image given below depicts an x-ray of the knee in a term baby. Which among thefollowing conditions is associated with it?A
questions.explanation: The deformity shown in the X-ray image is the absence of distal femoral epiphysis, which is atypical radiological feature of congenital hypothyroidism.X-ray findings in hypothyroidism• Absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses at birth.• Punctate epiphyseal dysgenesis (multiple foci of ossification)• Deformity or beaking of the 12th thoracic or 1st or 2nd lumbar vertebra• X-ray image of the skull shows large fontanels and wide sutures; wormian (intrasutural) bones;and, often, an enlarged and round sella turcica.Image below: The infant on the left with congenital hypothyroidism demonstrates the absence ofthe distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses, while in the normal infant on the right the distalfemoral epiphysis is present:AB590The image below shows small upper femoral epiphyses:The image below shows enlarged sella turcica and wormian bones (intrasutural):

questions.question: Ayesha is a 9th standard girl who presented with a neck swelling, which began more than ayear ago. Her mother says she is embarrassed about it and always covers her neck with a582shawl when she goes to school. Her menstrual cycles have also become irregular as of late.Blood tests reveal slightly elevated TSH levels and the presence of thyroid peroxidaseantibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The presence of thyroid peroxidase antibodies (TPO-Abs) and elevated thyroid-stimulatinghormone (TSH) level in a child with a goitre is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto)thyroiditis.Chronic lymphocytic (Hashimoto) thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease. Clinical presentation caninclude goitre, growth retardation, and other features of hypothyroidism. The thyroid is diffuselyenlarged, firm, and non-tender.591TSH is moderately elevated and TPO-Abs and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies (anti-Tg Abs) can bedetected.The image given below shows goitre due to Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

questions.question: A lady, with a history of a thyroid disorder and three prior abortions, delivered a femaleneonate prematurely at 34 weeks of gestation. In the newborn infant, tachycardia, irritability,and prominent eyes were noted and neonatal hyperthyroidism was suspected. Which of thefollowing statements is false about the condition?

options.A: Maternal Graves' disease is the most common cause of neonatal hyperthyroidism
options.B: It results from the transplacental passage of maternal stimulatory TSH receptor antibody
options.C: Microcephaly and frontal bossing with triangular facies are common clinical findings
options.D: Neonatal hyperthyroidism occurs in most infants born to mothers with a history of Graves'disease

questions.explanation: Neonatal hyperthyroidism occurs in only about 2% of infants born to mothers with a history ofGraves' disease. But maternal Graves' disease is by far the most common cause of neonatalhyperthyroidism.Neonatal hyperthyroidism (due to Grave's) results from the transplacental passage of maternalstimulatory thyrotropin/TSH receptor antibody (TSHR-Ab).Clinical features are as follows:• Low birth weight (IUGR)• Premature birth•Microcephaly.• Frontal bossing and triangular facies••Warm, moist skin• Irritability, hyperactivity, restlessness, poor sleep• TachycardiaNote:TSHR-Ab (TSH-R-stimulating antibodies) is another name for TSH-R-stimulatingimmunoglobulins (TSI).592

questions.question: A pregnant woman with a past history of Grave's disease has currently completed 36 weeks ofgestation. She underwent partial thyroidectomy 10 years back and has remained euthyroidsince then. The previous child had craniosynostosis. Which of the following antibodies ismost likely to be detected, if a cord blood sampling is done at delivery?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with a history of Graves' disease in the mother and craniosynostosis(neonatal Graves') in the previous child suggests that the fetus is at increased risk of neonatalGrave's disease. Thus, the antibody likely to be found at birth in the cord blood sampling is theTSH receptor stimulating antibody (TRSAb).Neonatal Graves is caused by the transplacental passage of TRSAbs from a mother with a historyof Graves' disease. The mothers can have•• Active Graves' disease• Graves' in remission• Prior history of Graves' treated with radioactive ablation or thyroidectomyTSRAbs bind to the receptor for TSH and stimulate cyclic AMP, leading to thyroid hyperplasiaand unregulated overproduction of thyroid hormone.

questions.question: A 4-year-old girl, a known case of celiac disease, presented to the pediatric endocrine clinicwith a history of neck swelling, tremor, and weight loss. On evaluation, she was found to have583Graves' disease. Other conditions that need to be screened in this patient include all of thefollowing except
questions.explanation: Type 2 Diabetes mellitus is not associated with Grave's disease.Conditions associated with Grave's disease (autoimmune diseases):• Diabetes mellitus type 1• Pernicious anaemia• Celiac disease• Vitiligo•Addison disease•• Alopecia areata• Myasthenia gravis

questions.question: An 11-year-old girl was brought by her parents with complaints of weight loss, increasedappetite, and a decline in scholastic performance. Following investigations, a diagnosis ofGrave's disease is made. Which of the following is the drug of choice for initial therapy?
questions.explanation: Methimazole is the initial drug of choice for treating Grave's disease (hyperthyroidism) inchildren.Option A: Propylthiouracil is not recommended in children because it is associated with fatalhepatotoxicity.Option C: Radioactive iodine is not preferred as the first-line treatment in hyperthyroidism forchildren.Option D: Levothyroxine is used to treat hypothyroidism.593

questions.question: Your unit chief has asked you to present the case of a teenager, who was admitted forevaluation of mental retardation, deaf-mutism and a gait disturbance. He also has asignificant patellar clonus. On general exam, you note a goitre but according to lab reports, heis apparently euthyroid. His pubertal development has also been normal. The most likelydiagnosis is
questions.explanation: The clinical presentation of a euthyroid patient with goitre as well as mental retardation,deaf-mutism, and normal pubertal development points towards neurological endemic cretinism.Endemic cretinism includes 2 different, but overlapping, syndromes: neurologic type andmyxedematous type. It is essentially the same disorder, phenotypically modified by the length andseverity of postnatal hypothyroidism. Neurological manifestations are interpreted as reflecting theeffects of maternal and fetal hypothyroxinemia, secondary to severe iodine deficiency, on thedeveloping nervous system. Both neurologic and myxedematous type can manifest neurologicsymptoms.Although neurological cretins are euthyroid, linear growth arrest lines in the long bones are oftendemonstrated radiologically, suggesting previous hypothyroidism.Option B: Graves disease includes a triad of hyperthyroidism with goitre, ophthalmopathy, anddermopathy (no mental retardation, deafness, or pyramidal signs).Option C: Pendred Syndrome is caused by a mutation in chloride-iodide transporter in thyroidand cochlea resulting in euthyroid/hypothyroid goitre and sensorineural hearing loss (pyramidalsigns like clonus are not seen).

questions.question: During a health outreach program in Sikkim, you come across 3 children from the samefamily, with goiter. Endemic cretinism was suspected. Which of the following can be amanifestation of this condition?
questions.explanation: Strabismus and spastic diplegias are among the manifestations of the neurological type ofendemic cretinism.Cretinism is a condition characterized by irreversible abnormalities in intellectualdevelopment. Endemic cretinism occurs due to the nutritional deficiency of iodine. It can beneurological cretinism or myxedematous cretinism. It is associated with severe, irreversiblemental retardation.594
